The case method is experiential
learning at its best.

And there's something
about when you

have to put yourself in
a situation and live it
that just sticks with you.

I'm an alum of the school,
and decades after graduating,
I still remember the cases.

I think the case
method is powerful

because it puts you into
the role of the protagonist,

and it forces you
to make decisions
with imperfect information.

And that's really reflective
of life out there in practice.

I spent 20 years in practice
before joining the faculty.

And every day, I was
having to make decisions
where the answer was unclear.

And the case method forces
students to do that every day

with the benefit of many other
smart minds in the room who

are often coming up with
risks and opportunities, pros

and cons that you
hadn't thought of.

I always liken teaching a case
to conducting an orchestra.

So I was a classical
violinist growing up.

The reality is I'm not
making the music, they are,

and my job is to
blend the instruments
in a way that creates magic.

We don't have a room
full of violins.

We don't have a room
full of trumpets.

What makes this rich
is the different music

and perspectives
that each student
brings to the conversation.

It also means that every
time it's different.

So one of my favorite
cases is a case

I wrote on the bankruptcy
of the city of Detroit.

I wrote that case
because I wanted

to challenge my
corporate restructuring

students to have to take
what they've learned

and apply it in a
different context.

What does it mean to
restructure a city?

Over the years, though, I teach
this case now very differently,

in large part due to the
contributions my students have

made in our classroom
discussions over the years.

And it's interesting
to my students

to have them come in
for what they think

is going to be a
finance conversation

and realize that
this is actually
about a lot more than that.
It's about questions of equity.

Should the city sell the art
it owns in its art museum

and use the money to
just pay the pensioners,
no other financial creditors.
Is that fair?
Is that OK?

And it's really about
questions of stakeholders.

The citizens of the City
of Detroit, largely Black,

largely poor are not traditional
constituents in a bankruptcy.

And so how do you think about
how to take care of them?

It's not just about
dollars and cents.
This is about more than finance.

And that if they're
going to go be leaders,

they've got to start grappling
with these questions.

So I find in teaching, there are
these moments where I can just

step back, and they have
conversation with each other.

They don't need me
to make the music.

And it's in those moments
that I just sit there and say,

"How lucky am I that
I get to witness
this level of conversation."

I also just say, "They're
ready, like they're

ready to go forward
and change the world."
